subject: Nipples Are Coming
event:
Let's turn from the latest cheating scandal involving the New England Patriots to a much more pleasant subject: breasts.

It is completely legal and acceptable for men to go shirtless in public throughout the United States.  But in many states and cities, women do not have the same right.  And heaven forfend there should be a "wardrobe malfunction" during the SuperBowl or similar event that exposes the country to a brief split-second glimpse of a female nipple (actually a pastie, but don't confuse us with facts).  GAME OF THRONES is often slammed for showing too many breasts as well.  As are other cable shows.  And of course you can't show them at all on broadcast television.

Only in America.  Why do so many people in this country go mad at the sight of a nipple? 

Anyway, this Friday at the Jean Cocteau we are screening FREE THE NIPPLE, the docudrama about the women who led the fight for nipple equality in New York City.

<lj-embed id="536"/>

New Mexico is not New York, of course... but our Cocteau staff will be appropriately clad to honor the fearless women who are the subject of the movie.

And we'll have Nipple-cakes too!

See you at the movies.

props.taglist: popular culture, jean cocteau, sex, movies, politics

comments.article: This is such a conundrum to me as a European where one of the more memorable movie scenes to usually be brought up include a copulating couple in small boat filled to the rim with fish.

comments.upictitle: I'll be in my bunk: Moose
comments.article: A boat filled with fish?
Nipples are magical - they make 6 lbs of fat look beautiful!
Legal in Austin, TX. :)

Why? Because nipples are what babies nurse from. Heaven forbid people are reminded of the functional use of the darn things. But to claim them solely as sexual object - part and parcel with the breast? Well, that's obscene and should be covered up like genetalia.

Don't you know this is how double standards work? Silly of you to think logically. Shame on you to use common sense.

And let's not even dip a toe into the whole argument about men's nipples and men deriving any pleasure from their own. That's... well... *whispers and looks about secretly* ... you know.
I find it humorous that television, movies etc wont bat an eyelash at showing gruesome violence, but will shy away from showing the human body. Of course, Im a fan of showing both things!
comments.subject: Irony is delicious

comments.article: Where is the damn "like" button for this comment...
comments.subject: Re: Irony is delicious

comments.article:
I didn't know what they were filming, but one day in the spring, a group of shirtless women were doing multiple takes running down Broadway shirtless toward the corner of Beaver St (there's a joke in there somewhere I think...). I happened to be walking back from lunch during this guerilla-style shoot so I might be in the background. If I showed up in this film, I wonder if the producers owe SAG some money for it ;) That reminds me, my dues are late.

It is completely legal for women to go topless in NYC, most people don't know that. And no, we weren't really phased when these women ran past during their takes, I was actually wondering what the big deal was--now I know.
comments.subject: I might be in the background if they show the shots near the "Wall St Bull"

comments.article:
I think this clip from Parks and Recreation should be included as well! ;)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_GjShjruHdU

I was involved in a discussion about nipples in a fan group a few months ago. I don't remember why it shifted to that subject but hey! Nipples! When I posted this PG-rated clip, which doesn't even *show* anything, the people involved freaked out. It's just a guy talking about nipples in the context of a pregnancy and then he gives them a really amusing alternative name (spoiler: "boob hats"). Apparently even talking about nipples is way too much for some people.

Only in America indeed. I don't get why female nudity is such a big taboo here, and I never have.
Everyone in the comment section is more than welcome to visit us here in Denmark. We're all shirtless in the parks in summer, female and male alike.

I know right. It would be really awesome if women had the freedom to express their breasts freely without getting arrested by the police. Allowing them to express themselves freely would both guarantee their liberty and also be fun for us men. Haha
comments.subject: Absolutely

comments.article:
DAMN, it's on like donkey kong, but full-on nipple style! George, if you need any help in the topless female department, I got a gaggle of ladiez on speed dial who take it off on a moment's notice. We'd be happy to supplement your staff if need by to support this truly epic and human rights-endeavor cause!

Jeffrey, of the infamous "Tight Tee Harem" from back in the DAY. Fellow playa out!

I have no problem with nudity (male or female) when it relates to the plot of a tv show or movie, but I do have a problem with it when it's clearly a desperate move to draw in more viewers. I think that's where many of the critiques of nudity in Game of Thrones come from too - not so much the fact that there is nudity, but that it was thrown in seemingly randomly just for the sake of having nudity. For example, it seems like every time the audience needs more backstory on a male character, it is delivered in a whorehouse scene. Because it's totally natural to talk about your relationship with your father while having a go with a prostitute, right?

And let's be honest, if we want to talk about double standards, the disproportionate ratio of female:male full nudity on GoT is a prime example.

Just another perspective. ;)

I agree. I do have no problem with nudity in TV shows or movies at all - if it fits the situation.

Just sometimes (not everytime, mind you) I cannot shake off the feeling the nudity is just there for itself, not for plot or character development, which I find a little sad.

The even bigger problem though (I mean, I can cope with a little extra nudity, I don't mind *that* much) - is as you said - the disproportionate ratio of female:male nudity. This is truly what goes on my nerves. Nobody counts if there has been one naked female more than a male one, but hontestly - how many minutes of naked male characters have we seen in comparison to female characters?
This is what comes closest to "sexism" if anything, considering the show. It's not about naked women, it's about the fact of the naked people showing up 90% are women, while there have been quite some plot/character opportunities to show male ones aswell.

(Edited typo)
Just sayin.
comments.subject: This post need tweaking

comments.article: My only issue with the nudity on Game of Thrones is that whether it's naked ladies or naked gay men--all the nudity seems intended for a male audience.  Pretty sure the only non-gay male nudity we've seen is Hodor.  I know it's cold at The Wall, but they can't stay dressed all the time...
Please consider that not all of us in the female audience are 100% heterosexual…

"New Mexico is not New York, of course... but our Cocteau staff will be appropriately clad to honor the fearless women who are the subject of the movie."

Hoping that there weren't any staff who, on potentially not feeling comfortable working in such (non)attire who were pressured verbally or nonverbally to do so, or who are missing out on wages because they weren't comfortable on that shift... until I got to that comment I was 100% for that, but the pressure to conform goes in all directions.

I also hope that the concessions stand staff are allowed to be appropriately attired to meet health and safety standards.  I don't want ANYONE's topless body near my popcorn, and they likely don't want their nipples free to be burned by hot butter & rogue kernels.
WORD!

I've never understood why it makes people go mad either.

The criticism I've seen online of the exposed breasts on Game of Thrones, though, has focused on there not being an equivalent amount of scenes where men are shirtless, and on the camera focusing on the woman disrobing while her partner isn't seen to.
OK, I've never even heard of "nipple equality", and I've been to Burning Man. But in any case, the fact that it's illegal (or even taboo) for women to be topless is absurd.

I was on the board of directors of our local radio station, when the super bowl wardrobe malfunction occurred.  The FCC came down on EVERYONE in the business.  The fines for violations of the indecency rules tripled.  Just one on-air 'Fuck' went from $7,000 fine to over $25,000!  Because of the HUGE overreaction to that one pastied nipple, the whole system of regulation became HYPER-ANAL!  I was totally mind blown over that whole thing!   Every Anti-nipple Troll in America (and around the world)must have grabbed the phone.  Nipple Haters!
comments.subject: Free the Nipples!

comments.article: Honi soit qui mal y pense!

Oddly enough,a British newspaper - in the loosest sense of the term - named The Sun has just ended its 44 year association with nipples, in part due to a passionate campaign, not only by feminists, against the inclusion of topless girls in what purports to be an organ of news dissemination, if not of serious debate and analysis. The girls themselves remain, I should add, but apparently their nipples are now hidden. Another publication which targets the same demographic, called The Daily Star is now the only nipple-friendly national newspaper in the UK, unless the barely literate Daily Sport is still in publication. How long this will remain the case is anyone's guess.
comments.subject: Coincidence

comments.article: The joke is, the pin-up was the least objectionable part of the whole 'newspaper' (a trashy tabloid from the Murdoch stable), and they were generally more wholesome looking than the 'count-the-ribs' women one tends to see half-naked in women's fashion magazines, who look more as if they belong in famine relief ads.
comments.subject: Re: Coincidence

comments.article: dear mr. martin, since you got a own cinema, how about supporting "what we do in the shadows"? it´s a great movie from great guys. i´m just a fan of the movie and it would be a shame if you muricans don´t get to see this flick, here is a link to their kickstarter-page https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/142<wbr />3546688/what-we-do-in-the-shadows-the-am<wbr />erican-release/
comments.subject: Cocteau screening

comments.article:
I saw WHAT WE DO IN THE SHADOWS last summer in Switzerland, at the Neuchatel Film Festival, and have been trying to book it ever since. Sadly, it appears that their American distributor is not going to give it to us, despite our best efforts. A pity. We could have done a lot with it -- special promotions, costumes, bloody marys.

So "muricans" will get to see this flick. Just not at my theatre.
And not for want of trying.
comments.subject: Re: Cocteau screening

comments.article: Much more useful than nipples on a breastplate.

It would appear my announcement of the disappearance of nipples in The Sun was premature. They're back, after less than a week, though today's edition, which for some reason I cannot quite explain I actually bought, has nipple-free photos of Miranda Kerr taken from her current campaign with whichever lingerie firm she's contracted to at the moment. Today's Guardian, meanwhile, has a lengthy article about how cynical The Sun's posture is, as well as a more entertaining one by the queen of cynics, Marina Hyde, about the perversity of gleefully showing nipples but disguising the word 'tits' with an asterisk:

http://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/lostinshowbiz/2015/jan/22/page-3-no-more-tits-in-the-sun-campaign-stop-the-asterisk?CMP=EMCNEWEML6619I2
comments.subject: T*ts are back

comments.article:
Bizarre, isn't it? I wonder how some people think! How do they bring themselves to have a bath or shower in case they see their own?

I don't see what the fuss is re: above-the-waist nudity in either sex; it's not like showing genitals.

This story continues to develop at a pace I can't quite keep track of. Each of my comments seems to be at least a day behind current developments. Here's another Guardianarticle with some responses to the return of the nipples (The Sun refers to a 'mammary lapse', though I'm not sure whether this is an allusion to the temporary disappearance of the naked breasts, or their sudden return):

http://www.theguardian.com/media/2015/jan/22/the-sun-topless-women-page-3

Today's Guardian has a full page article on the history of Page 3 and the resistance to it. While I haven't seen it, I assume The Sun has a pair of bare breasts. The choice, as always, is ours. Thank goodness for a free press.
comments.subject: Tits, t*ts, and more tits
